docs.lead_paragraph: Many Americans, upon seeing the number of servings of foods that the Food Guide Pyramid suggests should be consumed each day, say, ''Impossible!'' Among typical responses to these recommendations from the United States Departments of Agriculture and Health and Human Services: ''If I ate that much, I'd turn into a blimp'' and ''I can't possibly fit in all those grains and vegetables in the course of a normal day.'' But these and other objections mainly arise from a misunderstanding of just how much -- or, rather, how little -- makes up one serving of different foods and how easy it is to consume half or more of the day's recommended allowances in just one meal.

headline.main: Avoiding Confusion on Serving Size Is Key to Food Pyramid

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody describes how to avoid confusion over serving size of various foods on Food Guide Pyramid; graphics illustrate examples of serving sizes of dairy, meat, vegetables, fruit and grain, with their recommended daily allowance; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is no secret that Americans have short attention spans when it comes to exercise. Go to any gym, and people will be reading magazines and listening to music to keep themselves entertained on cardio machines. To encourage their disenchanted members, health clubs are installing consoles onto step machines and stationary bikes to allow users to surf the Internet, watch their own cable televisions, listen to CD's and call up past workout records each time they log on to a machine.

headline.main: Surfing the Internet Via the Step Machine

docs.abstract: Health clubs are installing consoles onto step machines and stationary bikes to allow users to surf the Internet, listen to CD's and call up past workout records each time they log on to a machine; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: For 28 years Bill Gaston, 41, has been running, and for 28 years he has veered in and out of the ''zone,'' a state of heightened attention in which exercise seems effortless and time passes easily. During one recent 3,000-meter race, Mr. Gaston, a long and lean magazine editor, re-entered that familiar territory: ''I grew strong. I got a beautiful feeling of being in gear. I was concentrating so much I felt like I was floating.'' Sighing, he added, ''You live for these kinds of experiences.'' What athletes call the zone, psychologists know as the less flashy ''flow.'' Either way, this intensely pleasurable, almost mystical, experience may be the key to helping those who loathe physical activity learn to enjoy it, according to a group of researchers in North America and Australia.

headline.main: A 'Flow' to Fuel the Reluctant Athlete

docs.abstract: Psychologists and researchers probe 'flow,' intensely pleasurable, almost mystical, experience of some athletes; flow is seen a state of heightened attention in which exercise seems effortless and time passes easily; photo of runners in Van Cortlandt Park in Bronx (M) '

docs.lead_paragraph: A Minnesota fertility clinic has offered a guarantee that men who have vasectomies reversed there will able to produce a pregnancy or it will pay for another fertility procedure. Reproductive Medicine and Infertility Associates of St. Paul said it was the first center to make such an offer, which includes a $6,000 credit to pay for another fertility technique if its vasectomy reversal fails to yield a pregnancy within a year. A vasectomy is a common surgical sterilization procedure that blocks the flow of sperm through a vessel known as the vas deferens.

headline.main: Help for Vasectomy Reversals That Fail

docs.abstract: Reproductive Medicine and Infertility Associates in St Paul, Minn, offers guarantee that men who have vasectomies reversed there will be able to produce a pregnancy or it will pay for another fertility procedure (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Michael Tighe made history in November. While on an American Airlines flight from Boston to Los Angeles with his wife, he suffered a cardiac arrest. A previously healthy 62-year-old jogger and public health officer in Boston, Mr. Tighe stopped breathing and had no pulse or blood pressure. His heart was beating chaotically, unable to send blood to his brain or other vital organs. But before his brain could die, a flight attendant, Kevin Dunn, quickly started CPR (cardiopulmonary resuscitation) while another attendant got the flight's first-aid kit. In it was a portable defibrillator, a device placed on board just three days earlier.

headline.main: A $3,000 'Fire Extinguisher' To Put Out Heart Attacks

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on growing use of portable automated external defibrillators to treat victims of cardiac arrest on planes, in shopping malls, and elsewhere; $3,000 device administers electric shocks through palm-size paddles to victim's heart to get its rhythm back on track; portable defibrillators are making a major difference in cardiac survival rates; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The expression ''take the money and run'' may resonate well among working wives who have pensions and are over the age of 45. These women are more likely to separate from their husbands than married women in the same age range who are employed but do not have pensions, according to a report released by the University of Michigan Institute for Social Research. In the first study of the relationship between pension wealth and marital dissolution, the researchers examined the marital, pension and employment status of women in 4,219 couples and placed working wives into three age categories: under 35, 35 to 44, and 45 and over.

headline.main: How Pensions Play in Divorce Court

docs.abstract: University of Michigan Institute for Social Research reports that 12 percent of pensioned women over 45 were separated from their husbands, while only 2 percent of women that age who were without pensions had experiencd marital dissolution (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A study has found the first direct evidence that the nutrient that makes tomatoes red may protect men against prostate cancer by shrinking tumors and slowing their spread. The findings were presented here today at a meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research. The nutrient, lycopene, has emerged as one of the trendiest of all nutritional supplements in recent years.

headline.main: Study Says Tomatoes May Limit Cancers

docs.abstract: Study finds first direct evidence that nutrient that makes tomatoes red may protect men against prostate cancer by shrinking tumors and slowing their spread; nutrient, lycopene, has emerged as one of trendiest of all nutritional supplements in recent years (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Annette Bauman of Great Neck, N.Y., turned 50 and seemed in perfect health -- no known ailments, no known emotional problems -- when she awoke in the night feeling extremely dizzy and deathly ill. ''I don't know what's happening,'' she told her husband. Then, within two hours, the sensation passed and she was fine. For a while.
docs.abstract: Medical researchers are studying possible emotional problems underlying patients who experience strange episodes of unexplained and severe hypertension occurring sporadically during periods of what appear to be perfectly normal health; Dr Samuel J Mann comments on his experience with patients suffering with intermittent and seemingly inexplicable attacks of severe hypertension; photo (M)
